body:
I think that Stack Overflow answer was targeting .NET 6.0, so it's not good for .NET 8.0.

Using `JsonSerializerOptions.Default` instead of `(JsonSerializerOptions)null` in `WorkOrderCustomPropertiesConverter` seems to solve the problem.  It looks like when CompiledModels are generated it drops the cast and leaves `null`, causing the failure.

However, in my real project I'm multi-targeting `net6.0;net8.0` and the same fix doesn't appear to work, so I'll have to reproduce that somehow.

OK, so the [official guidance](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/modeling/value-comparers?tabs=ef5) is to use `(JsonSerializerOptions)null` which fails in `dotnet-ef` 8.0.8.  Unless there's new documentation I can't find?

The fix, mentioned above is to use `JsonSerializerOptions.Default` in your `ValueConverter<TModel, TProvider>`.

Worse (for me) is that if you're storing a standard JSON Object, you're forced to use `.HasConversion()` and provide your own ValueConverter and ValueComparer, instead of relying on the default one, because the default one also gets generated with `null` instead of `(JsonSerializerOptions)null` and fails.

> When mapping a JSON Object (IntercompanySchedule.CustomCostings), you must provide your own .HasConversion if you want CompiledModels.

This is a Pomelo-specific issue. They need to update their json TypeMapping to be compatible with compiled models. However, this will still only work with EF Core 9 or newer.

issue.title: [release/9.0] Add explicit casts for generated null in method calls.

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Fixes #34515

### Description

When expressions generated as part of the compiled model contain a method call with a `null` argument they might fail to compile if there are ambiguous overloads. This is fixed by generating an explicit cast.

### Customer impact

The generated compiled model doesn't compile and needs to be fixed manually after every time it's regenerated.

### How found

Reported by a customer.

### Regression

No.

### Testing

Tests added.

### Risk

Low. This code is only invoked at design-time.

issue.title: CompiledModels fail to compile with JSON columns in 8.0.2 w/ EF Core 8

repository.name: Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql
repository.description: Entity Framework Core provider for MySQL and MariaDB built on top of MySqlConnector

issue.body:
When mapping a JSON Object using Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql 8.02, you must provide your own `.HasConversion` if you want your project to build after running dotnet-ef to generate compiled models.

I posted an issue on efcore and it got addressed quickly, but AndriySvyryd stated that a fix on the Pomelo side will be required.

Reproduction steps in the original post here: https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/34515, but `TestContext.cs` is clarified in the fourth post (third reply) with a better summary of the problem.

Andriy's post here: https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/34515#issuecomment-2307940137 confirms the problem and recommends you guys fix your TypeMappings (?).

TIA!

MySQL version: N/A (fails in compile)
Operating system: Windows 11
Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql version: 8.0.2
Microsoft.AspNetCore.App version: N/A (just building a context)
